It's a first-order upwind differencing scheme.


On Mon, 2008-04-14 at 14:13 +0000, avmokhov wrote:
> 
> Hello,
> Last two days I was trying to solve this problem. Indeed, for a free 
> hydrogen/air flame Cantera calculates temperatures substantially 
> lower than adiabatic ones (difference can be 40 K for a coarse grid). 
> It happens when multicomponent transport is used. For a mixture-
> averaged model calculations are fine. Refining grid helps a little 
> bit - difference decreases down to 20 K when number of grid points 
> approaches 300. Further refinement is impossible: Cantera has 
> problems with the noise when approximating derivatives. It seems for 
> me that something is nor correct with calculations of diffusion 
> terms. I did not dig in the code to check equations but it is 
> probably due to artificial diffusion on a coarse mesh. What 
> differences are used to approximate derivatives? Windward or central 
> difference?
> Best regards, Anatoli
> 
> --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Dave Goodwin" <dgoodwin@...> wrote:
> >
> > Could you send me an example flame script or program that shows the 
> problem? Thanks.
> > 
> > --- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Matei I. Radulescu" <matei@> wrote:
> > >
> > > When one computes the the free-flame structure (say H2+air at 
> PTN),
> > > the equilibrium temperature obtained is different from the true
> > > adiabatic flame temperature obtained via a direct equilibrium
> > > calculation, using the same thermo data. The differences are on 
> the
> > > order of 10K for the example given. Likewise, the enthalpy in the
> > > flame of the equilibrium products is NOT found equal to reactants
> > > enthalpy, although theoretically, they should be equal. This 
> leads me
> > > to suspect that the non-conservative flame calculations introduces
> > > order 1 errors in the species concentrations of the products,
> > > consistent with the results of the simulations! Are these
> > > *acceptable* errors???
> > >
> >
> 
> 
> 
> 
>
